video.title: APIs for Beginners 2023 - How to use an API (Full Course / Tutorial)
video.description:
What is an API? Learn all about APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) in this full tutorial for beginners. You will learn what APIs do, why APIs exist, and the many benefits of APIs. APIs are used all the time in programming and web development so it is important to understand how to use them.

You will also get hands-on experience with a few popular web APIs. As long as you know the absolute basics of coding and the web, you'll have no problem following along.

This course has been updated from a previous version.

💻 Teacher’s Notes: https://twil.io/notes-api-course

🎥 Course created by Craig Dennis, Developer Educator at Twilio
🐦 Craig on Twitter: @craigsdennis

⭐️ Contents ⭐️
Unit 1 - What is an API
⌨️ Video 1 - Welcome (0:00:00)
⌨️ Video 2 - Defining Interface (0:04:50)
⌨️ Video 3 - Defining API (0:08:49)
⌨️ Video 4 - Remote APIs (0:13:59)
⌨️ Video 5 - How the web works (0:18:17)
⌨️ Video 6 - RESTful API Constraint Scavenger Hunt (0:23:21)

Unit 2 - Exploring APIs
⌨️ Video 1 - Exploring an API online (0:29:06)
⌨️ Video 2 - Using an API from the command line  (0:45:01)
⌨️ Video 3 - You go Curl (0:56:20)
⌨️ Video 4 - Using tools to explore APIs (1:14:21)
⌨️ Video 5 - More tools for your API exploring toolbox (1:36:20)
⌨️ Video 6 - Using Helper Libraries (1:48:34)

Unit 3 - All Together Now
⌨️ Video 1 - Introducing the Project (2:15:30)
⌨️ Video 2 - Serverless (2:23:30)
⌨️ Video 3 - Writing a Server Side API (2:37:08)
⌨️ Video 4 - Fetching Results on the Client from our Server (2:56:54)
⌨️ Video 5 - Wrap Up (3:05:29)

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Nattira Maneerat
👾 Heather Wcislo
👾 Serhiy Kalinets
👾 Erdeniz Unvan
👾 Justin Hual
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 Otis Morgan

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Gerald English
topLevelComment.text:
Definitely not for beginners and I haven't learned that much, only a few key words like REST, CRUD, CURL, POSTMAN and the course has taken 3 hours of my life...
I don't know why you're using Twilio as everything... you said Postman is complicated, Twilio is on a next level of 'complicated'...
Why not use Visual Studio Code and start from scratch using only this editor and show us how to start and finish A WORKING PROJECT. You're trying to teach about an API. So start a project in VSC, take a dad jokes API as an example and teach us how everything works. The main objective to use an API is for a website to be interactive and right now I don't even know how to implement an API on a website so I can extract a user's custom query and show that data on a website as a result...

That's the problem with tutorials right now, they're very long and not practical unfortunately.

topLevelComment.author: AdoraWyne
topLevelComment.text:
Note to myself:
*I* - Interface for developer, hiding away the abstraction implementation-wise.
*API* - contracts, API defines how it is expected to be used, & defines how we expect to receive by using it. Not necessarily constraint to what I learned before - HTTP protocol. For example:
10:14 : Craig talking about *JS API* here: by calling one of the JS API - toUpperCase() function to turn a string to uppercase. So we don't have to worry about how it works under the hood. It hides away the abstraction. We just call this method and voila, the string turns to uppercase!
12:16 : Frameworks provide API that allows you to extend what has been provided to make it your own. Again, you don't need to know how it works but you do need to know how to implement it. Just like, we need to know how to call toUpperCase() function to turn a string to uppercase. Framework often comes with certain rules you need to comply with, like Express- requesting/importing certain things to add routes.
13:33 : What is the API Craig's hinting about? Youtube API? I clicked on this video, and my browser sent a data request of this video to YT Server, then YT sent me back the data requested and display the video on my browser. (HTTP)

replies.author: AdoraWyne
replies.text:
*RESTful API Constraint Scavenger Hunt*
1. Client-Server Architecture : A client request, A server respond
2. Stateless : After the resquest/respond cycle finished, it's all done. The browser/webpage will not remember it anymore. But to keep you login to a page, the info is stored in Header of each request.

- Requesting a resource (U*R*L /I). The term- resource to reference an object. Resource & Collections (data).
- CRUD - Creating (POST), Reading (GET), Updating (PUT), Deleting (DELETE)
- Eg: Browser sends a GET request to an URL/endpoint. Server responds with HTTP Header & Body. 
- Normally Body is in JSON format (JS Object Notation)

replies.author: AdoraWyne
replies.text:
*How the web works*
18:43 - How web works? keyword: Client, Server, URL or URI (Universal Resource Locator/Identifier), HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol)
19:46 - HTT*P*, Protocol: respond correctly to a specific request. The browser creates an HTTP request for you. Common HTTP verbs/request methods- GET, POST, PUT, DELETE.
20:14 - HT*T*P, Transfer: Server received the request *transferred* from client.
20:27 - Respond part - body - webpage contains HTML (*HT*TP).
20:58 - HTTP - Stateless - after the request/respond cycle is done, everything is all done and the browser will not remember it anymore. (But cookies allow us to make HTTP stateful)
21:47 - Passing info of the request: query string param or Headers.
*HEADER in Request*:
- the key-value pairs, both request&respond have it.
- all the relevant information about your request including in what format the client device expects to receive the data.
- allow you to specify e.g. the language of the response and content-type (the format of the info I expect to receive).
Whereas, Body in Response contains the actual request data.

-  22:22 - Can also embed authentication info in the header in each request (Cookies & Session?)
22:29 - *Header in Respond* - contains HTTP status code (& other stuff).

replies.author: AdoraWyne
replies.text:
14:01 Remote API - remotely control your device (remote control). e.g. Shazam, remotely assessing what is the song playing atm with the database. It’s very fast (super fast computational power), its process in the cloud.
16:45 REST, Representational State Transfer (also remote API, another example- GraphQL)

topLevelComment.author: Sanket Hande
topLevelComment.text: what’s the difference between old and new one?

replies.author: Craig Dennis
replies.text: Great question Sanket! This one uses new REST API clients in addition to Postman (since Postman got harder to navigate as a newcomer). Instead of focussing on Python and JavaScript, we leaned into JavaScript and simplified the app creation process (as that wasn't what folks are here to learn). Spotify and Twilio updated a ton, and folks were having a hard time navigating around. Also I beatbox.
